game_theory.title: John Nash and Game Theory (Pure Theory)
summary: Game theory is a formal framework for analyzing strategic interaction among rational decision-makers.
John Nash introduced the equilibrium concept that now bears his name, showing that every finite game has at least one equilibrium in mixed strategies.

key_concepts.definition: A model defined by players, available actions (strategies), and payoffs for each outcome.
A complete plan of action a player will follow in a game.
A numerical representation of each player’s preferences over outcomes.
A strategy profile where no player can improve their payoff by unilaterally deviating, given others’ strategies.
A probability distribution over pure strategies.
A strategy that yields at least as good a payoff as any other strategy, regardless of opponents’ choices.
A strategy that maximizes a player’s payoff given beliefs about other players’ strategies.

core_results: Existence: Every finite game has at least one Nash equilibrium in mixed strategies (Nash, 1950/1951).
Interpretation: Equilibrium as mutual consistency of best responses; stability under unilateral deviation.
Extensions: Equilibrium refinements and dynamics (e.g., trembling-hand perfection, evolutionary stability) build on Nash’s baseline concept.
how_to_read: Start with normal-form games (payoff matrices) and compute best responses.
Identify pure-strategy equilibria via best-response intersections.
If none exist, solve for mixed strategies by making opponents indifferent between pure actions on support.
Check deviations: verify that each strategy is a best response to the others.
